Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2009 06:50AM LML wrote:  I had this procedure done last year, and the worst thing for me was the mammogram part!  I asked why they couldn't give me the local before they squashed me, and they said they needed to place the local anesthetic very specifically.  They said they needed the mammogram to guide him as to where to put the local and then the wire.  The doctor left the room while the technician did my compression, and I was very anxious for him to come back.  The wire part was just a little uncomfortable.  The local worked very quickly, and then I was free from the mammogram machine, YEAH!
Posts.Title: does the wire hurt in an excisional biopsy?? debnyc JCinAZ

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2008 02:18PM LML wrote: I just had a bilat mast on Aug 19, 2008.  The incisions are pretty much horizontal on both sides.  They incorporated my lumpectomy scar which was above my right nipple.  I had tissue expanders put in and they were able to fill me with 500cc which I hear is good.  Of course, it feels like i bench pressed an elephant.  I had skin sparing mastectomy and right now there seems to be a couple of areas on each side that are sort of puckered.  I'm hoping this means that this is room to grow when I get my next fill on Sept 3rd.
Posts.Title: bilateral incisions--which way is best? harmonysun otter

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2008 06:14AM LML wrote: I had a bilat mast on Aug 19 with 2 nodes removed.  I was just diagnosed with blood clots in my right leg.  I'm so mad and frustrated.  Just when I was starting to feel more normal, this happens.  I was walking, eating right and doing everything I was supposed to.  I wore the boots through surgery and the entire day afterward.  Now I wish I wore them longer, maybe this would have helped? mred, is it a localized pain or a general overall cramping?  In my case, it was a specific spot that was hurting, and when they ultrasounded it, they said 2 blood clots.  I am seeing a hematologist today.  I guess I need to feel grateful that it was in my calf and not my thigh.  They told me I would have been admitted to the hospital immediately if it was in my thigh. I hope you have answers quickly.
Posts.Title: Leg pain associated w/ node removal? mred7 LML

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2008 06:25AM LML wrote: I just saw a reconstructive surgeon today who said she has seen some poor results from using Alloderm, so she doesn't use it. She uses Valium to relax the chest muscle.  I spoke with another plastic surgeon who uses Botox to relax the chest muscle, but I have heard this is something very new.  I hope this information  helps!
Posts.Title: alloderm ocean_snow lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: LML wrote: I just had a bilateral mastectomy on August 19th with immediate tissure expanders placed at the same time.  2 nodes were removed and everything seemed to be going quite well. Then, I had a very strange side effect fromVicadin and was curious if anyone else has experienced anything similar.  The day of surgery I noticed that I was being very particular about things that would not normally bother me.  It was like I was suddenly suffering from Obsessive compulsive disorder.  I couldn't stand to see the closet door open or the suitcase left on the bed.  If my husband didn't do what i wanted immediately, I would get really upset.  Once I was home the next day, my son couldn't find my discharge papers and I freaked!  I was crying hysterically even though my rational mind knew that I had all the information I needed already.  My dosages were all on the prescription bottles.  However, my OCD/Vicadin mind kept strongly saying "I want those 2 pieces of paper, and I want them NOW!"  The doctors office offered to fax over a copy of the papers, and assured me I would be fine, but at that moment nothing could console me.  I wanted what I wanted when I wanted it, and give it to me! I felt like a 2 year old having a tantrum.  I could feel my chest swelling from the heaving from the hysterical crying.  I knew i was doing myself no good, but could not shake the feeling. IfI have indeed had an insight into what people suffering from OCD go through, I truly feel for them.  I would find it very difficult to deal with those feelings on a daily basis. I'm happy to say that my prescription was changed to percocette, and everything is so much better now.  Of course, I'm still sore, but my mental state has improved dramatically. Anyone else out there have a similar story? DCIS diagnosed April 2008, Grade 3, Comedo Necrosis Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Vicadin trouble after mastectomy LML Kleenex

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2008 11:57PM LML wrote: I am having a bilateral mastectomy tomorrow morning.  GULP!  It took me a long time to decide.  I was diagnosed with DCIS, grade 3 back in April, and have taken much time and research to make my decision.  I feel strangely calm today, but it has been an emotional rollercoaster these past months.  One of the factors in my decision, unfortunately, was thinking about insurance coverage.  I have decent insurance now, but I have been in situations where my coverage was very expensive and minimal.  If I had to deal with a recurrence without good insurance, it could break the bank.  I wish you all the best thoughts in your decision making.  Just remember to do what is right for you, no one else can tell you how to feel.
Posts.Title: Need to decide one breast or two? catemarie catemarie

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2008 01:56PM LML wrote: I had a bilat mast on Aug 19.  My first post op appt is August 26th and I am hoping to lose these drains!  My plastic surgeon told me that only about 10% of her patients can remove the drains after one week.  She says 2 weeks is more the norm.  I just did my drains and one had 5cc and the other 11cc.  I'm at about 30-35cc a day.  I think if you try to minimize your arm movements, you'll slow down the amount of fluid draining. I wish you luck that your draining slows down, so that you can get rid of those drains.  I know what a pain they are.  I was told I can't shower until they're out, so needless to say I feel YUCK.  My husband took me to a salon to get my hair washed, and I cried from being so happy to have at least my hair look and smell decent. Just remember, this is the time in your life to let others do for you, so that you can get better faster.  I think it's hard for women to do this, we're used to being the doers.  Have patience with yourself, and think healing thoughts. All my best, Lara
Posts.Title: How long do drains stay in? HeatherBLocklear new2bc

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2008 10:38AM LML wrote: ango74, I'm surprised you have to convince your surgeon to do what you want.  If you want both, he should support your decision, I think.  My surgeon made a comment about my taking the "good breast" that it would be taking off a perfectly fine part of my body, but i told her that I didn't want to wait and worry about getting a reccurence.  She didn't agree with me, but didn't give me a fight.  I know you are very young at 33, I'm 41, and part of my reasoning was that I have a lot of years ahead (hopefully)for potential future problems with the "good breast."
Posts.Title: AUGUST/SEPT SURGERIES?? harmonysun museumlover

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2008 10:27AM LML wrote: wyndywy,  I thought insurance had to cover bilateral by federal law?  I would fight that.  Sometimes, they are so used to saying no that you have to remind them that they can say yes.  I was told that even if you want to remove the "good breast", they have to cover it.  I was also told that if you need work on the breast you keep, such as a lift for symmetry they have to cover that too.  Don't give up.  Some insurance companies are programmed to say no to everything, counting on the fact that a percentage of people will just accept it.  Fight for what you want!!!  Make them listen.
Posts.Title: AUGUST/SEPT SURGERIES?? harmonysun museumlover

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2008 05:18PM LML wrote: My bilat mast on Aug 19th was going well,and then I developed a blood clot in my right calf and now hives from the antibiotic Keflex.  I had such a vision of a quick recovery, and I'm getting frustrated by these setbacks.  I am now injecting myself twice a day with Lovenox, and then Cumedin will start once my drains are gone.  I'm going to see both of my surgeons tomorrow, and will probably get my drains out.  I can't wait to be free from these things! I know there are a lot of you out there that have it worse than me, but I needed to vent. Take care everyone.
Posts.Title: AUGUST/SEPT SURGERIES?? harmonysun museumlover

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2008 10:22AM LML wrote: I just had a bilateral mastectomy on August 19th with immediate tissue expanders put in.  Everything went well, except for a strange reaction to vicadin.  I had a weird episode of what I guess you would call OCD.  I suddenly couldn't stand to see a closet door left open or the suitcase on the bed.  It was crazy!  I was able to come home the day after surgery at 6:00pm.  I had times when I wished I had stayed to get the extra attention, but i thik that was related to the OCD thing.  I felt like a spoiled brat, I wanted what I wanted when I wanted it and if I didn't get it, I cried like a baby.  Physically, things are going well.  Pain is manageable, it more like muscle soreness instead of acute pain, although I have one spot under my left breast that will burn when I'm getting out of bed.  I miss the adjustable hospital bed!  The good news is my lymph nodes were negative, so no chemo, yeah!  I just need to get through the whole reconstruction process, and get back to normal life.
Posts.Title: AUGUST/SEPT SURGERIES?? harmonysun museumlover

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2008 01:02AM LML wrote: I had a wire localization biopsy in April 2008.  I wish they had given me a sedative or something prior.  They knew I would be going under general anethesia right after the wire was inserted, so I feel it's better for the patient to be as calm as possible.  I didn't think the procedure would be so bad, I mean I read how it was done, local anesthetic, mammogram guided placement of the wire.  It sounded pretty simple.  I guess I didn't count on the freak out factor of "there's a wire sticking out of my chest!"  Plus, I felt the wire being inserted at the very end.  It seems most of these ladies breezed through it, so I hope it will be the same for you.  If I had it to do over again, I would ask for something to put me in a mellow state before.  After all, it does no good to go into surgery crying and hyperventalating. All the best to you, think healing thoughts, take care of yourself mentally and physically.
Posts.Title: Wire guided lumpectomy? mommy3abm KAK
